user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketSendTo:
```c
int32 OS_SocketSendTo(osal_id_t sock_id, const void *buffer, size_t buflen, const OS_SockAddr_t *RemoteAddr)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buflen);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(RemoteAddr);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_DATAGRAM)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketSendTo_Impl(&token, buffer, buflen, RemoteAddr);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketSendTo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_SocketSendTo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *buffer, size_t buflen,
                           const OS_SockAddr_t *RemoteAddr)
{
    int                             os_result;
    socklen_t                       addrlen;
    const struct sockaddr *         sa;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    sa = (const struct sockaddr *)&RemoteAddr->AddrData;
    switch (sa->sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in6);
            break;
#endif
        default:
            addrlen = 0;
            break;
    }

    if (addrlen != RemoteAddr->ActualLength)
    {
        return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
    }

    os_result = sendto(impl->fd, buffer, buflen, MSG_DONTWAIT, sa, addrlen);
    if (os_result < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("sendto: %s\n", strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return os_result;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected the following code paths and found no modifications of function parameter variables (pointer parameters) that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8:

- OS_SocketSendTo: parameters (sock_id, buffer, buflen, RemoteAddr) are only tested (via macros) or passed to other functions. The local variable token is created and its address is passed; token is not a function parameter and modifying it is permitted. There is no assignment to any of the function parameters (no e.g. RemoteAddr = ..., buffer = ..., or sock_id = ...).

- OS_SocketSendTo_Impl: parameters are all const pointers or values. The code dereferences *token and RemoteAddr to access pointed-to objects (allowed), computes sa from RemoteAddr->AddrData, and passes buffer/buflen to sendto. There is no reassignment of the pointer parameters themselves.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById / OS_ObjectIdRelease and related transaction routines: the functions accept OS_object_token_t *token and modify the object pointed to (token->obj_idx, token->obj_id, etc.), which is allowed by the rule. No reassignment of the pointer parameter itself occurs.

- Macros OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_CHECK_SIZE, and OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: these evaluate parameters but do not perform assignments that modify the pointer parameter variables.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided code that appear to violate Rule 17.8 (no function parameter pointers are reassigned; only the pointees are modified where applicable). If you want, I can also scan additional files or higher-level macros (e.g., implementations of OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish/Init/ConvertToken) to ensure those do not reassign pointer parameters.
